metadata.title: ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§ö‡•á ‡§µ‡•á‡§° (Love of Reading)
metadata.subject: Marathi
metadata.description: A story about a young person who develops an intense passion for reading (‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§ö‡•á ‡§µ‡•á‡§°). They read every book they can find, visit the library regularly, stay up late reading, and are transported to new worlds through books. Parents are initially worried but eventually support the habit when they see its positive effects. The story celebrates the joy and transformative power of reading. Grammar focus: ‡§â‡§≠‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•á (Conjunctions) ‚Äî words that join words, phrases, or sentences together, with four types: additive (‡§Ü‡§£‡§ø), adversative (‡§™‡§£), alternative (‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç‡§µ‡§æ), and causal (‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£/‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§£‡•Ç‡§®).

preAssessment.question: What does '‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§ö‡•á ‡§µ‡•á‡§°' literally mean in English?

options.B: Conjunctions ‚Äî words that join words, phrases, or sentences

preAssessment.question: Which type of conjunction is '‡§™‡§£' (pan) in Marathi?
The Marathi conjunction '‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç‡§µ‡§æ' (kinwa) is used to express:

concepts.title: Story About Reading Passion
concepts.content: The story '‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§ö‡•á ‡§µ‡•á‡§°' (Love of/Obsession with Reading) follows a young student who discovers the joy of books and becomes completely absorbed in reading. They find books on every topic fascinating, visit the library whenever possible, read late into the night, and sometimes even forget meals because they are lost in a book. '‡§µ‡•á‡§°' in Marathi means an obsession or passionate love for something ‚Äî '‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§ö‡•á ‡§µ‡•á‡§°' captures that intense, joyful state of being completely absorbed in reading. The parents initially worry ('Is this healthy? Is the child sleeping enough?') but gradually realize that this passion is developing the child's mind, empathy, and knowledge.

examples.text: The child visits the library regularly ‚Äî exploring books on science, history, stories, poetry, and more.
Reading late into the night ‚Äî the room is dark except for the reading light, the world silent.
Parents worried at first ‚Äî too much reading, not sleeping enough! But they see the child's growth.
The story celebrates the state of 'being lost in a book' ‚Äî a joy that readers across the world know.

keyPoints: '‡§µ‡•á‡§°' means obsession/passionate love ‚Äî '‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§ö‡•á ‡§µ‡•á‡§°' is the beautiful state of being addicted to reading.
The story shows reading as a transformative experience ‚Äî it opens up new worlds.
Parents' initial concern shifts to support when they see reading's positive effects.
Public libraries (‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç‡§•‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ø) play a crucial role in making books accessible to children.
The story encourages students to develop their own '‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§ö‡•á ‡§µ‡•á‡§°' ‚Äî a lifelong passion for reading.
concepts.funFact: Maharashtra has a strong reading culture ‚Äî the Marathi literary festival 'Akhil Bharatiya Marathi Sahitya Sammelan' (All India Marathi Literature Conference) is the largest gathering of Marathi writers and readers in the world, held every year in a different Maharashtra city!
concepts.textbookRef: Chapter 9, Pages 28-34 ‚Äî Maharashtra Board 7th Grade Marathi (Second Language)

concepts.title: Benefits of Reading
concepts.content: Reading (‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§®) is one of the most powerful tools for learning and growth. The story shows its transformative effects: (1) Knowledge: reading books on any topic gives information and understanding that formal school alone cannot provide. (2) Vocabulary: reading regularly is the best way to grow vocabulary in any language. (3) Empathy: reading stories about different people's lives builds the ability to understand others' feelings. (4) Imagination: books stimulate creative thinking and visualization. (5) Concentration: regular reading builds the ability to focus for longer periods. (6) Better language skills: extensive reading improves both reading and writing ability in Marathi and other languages.

examples.text: Knowledge expansion: every book you read adds to your understanding of the world beyond school textbooks.
Empathy: reading stories about different people's lives helps you understand and respect different experiences.
Imagination: books describe worlds, places, and events ‚Äî your mind creates vivid pictures, building creativity.
Better writing: students who read extensively write better ‚Äî they absorb good sentence structure and vocabulary.

keyPoints: Reading builds vocabulary ‚Äî the best way to grow Marathi vocabulary is to read widely.
Reading develops empathy ‚Äî understanding characters' feelings and situations builds emotional intelligence.
Reading improves concentration and focus ‚Äî a skill valued in all areas of study and life.
Every book you read adds to your knowledge bank ‚Äî history, science, culture, geography.
Maharashtra's rich literary tradition offers thousands of books for young readers in Marathi.
concepts.funFact: Research shows that students who read for pleasure for just 15-20 minutes a day show significantly better academic performance across ALL subjects ‚Äî not just language. Reading in Marathi also strengthens a student's ability to read and understand Hindi, Sanskrit, and even English, because of shared vocabulary roots!

concepts.title: Libraries and Books in Marathi Culture
concepts.content: Maharashtra has a rich tradition of libraries (‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç‡§•‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ø) and reading culture. '‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç‡§•' means a sacred/important book, '‡§Ü‡§≤‡§Ø' means a place/house ‚Äî so '‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç‡§•‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ø' literally means 'house of important books.' Key libraries in Maharashtra: (1) Pune's Deccan College Library ‚Äî one of India's oldest academic libraries; (2) Mumbai's Asiatic Society Library ‚Äî established 1804, with rare manuscripts; (3) Nashik's Sarvajanik Vacanalaya ‚Äî a historic public library; (4) Every village in Maharashtra aims to have a ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç‡§•‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ø (public library). Maharashtra's literacy rate is above national average, and the state has a vibrant Marathi publishing industry.

examples.text: '‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç‡§•‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ø' = library: ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç‡§• (important book) + ‡§Ü‡§≤‡§Ø (place/house) = house of books.
Marathi children's books: Balbharati publishes educational books; other publishers like Manoj, Rajhans provide story books.
Many Maharashtra villages have 'Vacanalaya' (reading rooms) ‚Äî community spaces for reading and discussion.
Marathi literature has great children's authors ‚Äî books by Saraswati Chandratreya, P.L. Deshpande are classics.

keyPoints: Maharashtra has a 1,000+ year tradition of Marathi literature ‚Äî from Dnyaneshwar (13th c.) to modern authors.
Balbharati (Maharashtra State Textbook Bureau) ‚Äî publishes school books and children's literature.
Joining a library provides access to hundreds of books for free ‚Äî a great resource for students.
Reading Marathi books beyond the textbook greatly enriches language skills and cultural understanding.
concepts.funFact: P.L. Deshpande (Pulacha La Deshpande, 1919-2000), popularly known as 'Pu La,' was Maharashtra's most beloved humourist, writer, and social commentator. His books like 'Vyakti ani Valli' and 'Aapla Pu La' are hilarious, warm portraits of Maharashtrian life ‚Äî any 7th grader who reads them will love Marathi literature forever!
concepts.textbookRef: Chapter 9, Pages 28-34 ‚Äî Libraries and Marathi culture

concepts.title: Conjunctions: ‡§â‡§≠‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•á ‚Äî Definition
concepts.content: Conjunctions (‡§â‡§≠‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•á) are words that join two words, phrases, or sentences together. '‡§â‡§≠‡§Ø' means both/two, '‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•Ä' means connecting/joining ‚Äî so ‡§â‡§≠‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•Ä = connecting both sides. '‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•á' reminds us these are indeclinable words (do not change for gender/number). Conjunctions in Marathi work the same way as in English ‚Äî they link ideas and show the relationship between them (addition, contrast, choice, cause). Examples: '‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§Ü‡§£‡§ø ‡§§‡•Ä ‡§∂‡§æ‡§≥‡•á‡§§ ‡§ó‡•á‡§≤‡•ã' (I and she went to school ‚Äî ‡§Ü‡§£‡§ø joins both). '‡§§‡•ã ‡§•‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ ‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡§æ ‡§™‡§£ ‡§Ü‡§≤‡§æ' (He was tired but he came ‚Äî ‡§™‡§£ shows contrast).

examples.text: Addition: '‡§Ü‡§£‡§ø' (and): '‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§§‡•ã ‡§Ü‡§£‡§ø ‡§≤‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•ã' ‚Äî He reads and writes.
Contrast: '‡§™‡§£' (but): '‡§§‡•ã ‡§π‡•Å‡§∂‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á ‡§™‡§£ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§π‡§®‡§§‡•Ä ‡§®‡§æ‡§π‡•Ä' ‚Äî He is clever but not hardworking.
Alternative: '‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç‡§µ‡§æ' (or): '‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡§æ ‡§ö‡§π‡§æ ‡§π‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ï‡•â‡§´‡•Ä?' ‚Äî Do you want tea or coffee?
Cause: '‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£' (because): '‡§§‡•ã ‡§Ü‡§≤‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ ‡§§‡•ã ‡§Ü‡§ú‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡§æ' ‚Äî He didn't come because he was sick.

keyPoints: ‡§â‡§≠‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•á = conjunctions ‚Äî words that join parts of a sentence or two sentences.
They are '‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•á' ‚Äî they do not change their form for gender, number, or case.
Four main types: ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§ï (additive), ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§ï (alternative), ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§®‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§ï (adversative), ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§ï (causal).
Conjunctions make writing flow smoothly and show the logical relationship between ideas.
Using varied conjunctions makes Marathi writing and speaking richer and more sophisticated.
concepts.funFact: The conjunction '‡§Ü‡§£‡§ø' (and) is one of the most frequently used words in Marathi ‚Äî appearing in almost every sentence of normal speech. Interestingly, it comes from the Sanskrit root '‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å' (after/following) ‚Äî showing how 'and' was originally conceived as 'what follows next'!

concepts.title: Four Types of Marathi Conjunctions
concepts.content: The four types of Marathi conjunctions (‡§â‡§≠‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•á): (1) ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§ï (Additive) ‚Äî add/accumulate ideas together. Words: ‡§Ü‡§£‡§ø (and), ‡§§‡§∏‡•á‡§ö (as well as), ‡§µ (and), ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø (moreover). Example: '‡§§‡•ã ‡§ó‡§æ‡§§‡•ã ‡§Ü‡§£‡§ø ‡§®‡§æ‡§ö‡§§‡•ã.' (2) ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§ï (Alternative) ‚Äî give a choice between options. Words: ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç‡§µ‡§æ (or), ‡§Ö‡§•‡§µ‡§æ (or), ‡§®‡§æ‡§π‡•Ä‡§§‡§∞ (otherwise). Example: '‡§§‡•Ç ‡§ú‡§æ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§≤ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡§∂‡•Ä‡§≤?' (3) ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§®‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§ï (Adversative) ‚Äî show contrast or opposition. Words: ‡§™‡§£ (but), ‡§™‡§∞‡§Ç‡§§‡•Å (but/however), ‡§§‡§∞‡•Ä (still/yet), ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ (however). Example: '‡§§‡•ã ‡§•‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ ‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡§æ ‡§™‡§£ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§ï‡•á‡§≤‡•á.' (4) ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§ï (Causal) ‚Äî show reason/cause. Words: ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ (because), ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§£‡•Ç‡§® (therefore/so), ‡§∏‡§¨‡§¨ (therefore). Example: '‡§§‡•ã ‡§Ü‡§≤‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ ‡§™‡§æ‡§ä‡§∏ ‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡§æ.'

examples.text: ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§ï (Alternative): ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç‡§µ‡§æ, ‡§Ö‡§•‡§µ‡§æ ‚Äî '‡§ö‡§π‡§æ ‡§π‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§¶‡•Ç‡§ß?' (Do you want tea or milk?)

keyPoints: Type 1 ‚Äî ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§ï (additive): ‡§Ü‡§£‡§ø, ‡§§‡§∏‡•á‡§ö, ‡§µ ‚Äî add ideas together.
Type 2 ‚Äî ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§ï (alternative): ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç‡§µ‡§æ, ‡§Ö‡§•‡§µ‡§æ, ‡§®‡§æ‡§π‡•Ä‡§§‡§∞ ‚Äî give choices.
Type 4 ‚Äî ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§ï (causal): ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£, ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§£‡•Ç‡§®, ‡§∏‡§¨‡§¨ ‚Äî show reason or result.
Exam tip: identify the relationship between sentences to determine which type of conjunction to use.
concepts.funFact: The conjunction '‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§£‡•Ç‡§®' (therefore/so) has an interesting structure: '‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§£‡•á' means 'it is said/supposedly' ‚Äî so '‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§£‡•Ç‡§®' originally meant 'saying this' or 'by reason of what was said' ‚Äî evolving into a conjunction meaning 'therefore.' Marathi conjunctions often have fascinating etymological stories!
concepts.textbookRef: Chapter 9, Pages 28-34 ‚Äî Four types of conjunctions

test.question: What does the Marathi word '‡§µ‡•á‡§°' mean in the title '‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§ö‡•á ‡§µ‡•á‡§°'?
test.explanation: '‡§µ‡•á‡§°' in Marathi means an intense passion, obsession, or deep love for something. '‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§ö‡•á ‡§µ‡•á‡§°' literally means 'the obsession/passion of reading.' It is used in a positive sense here ‚Äî the kind of joyful, all-consuming love for books that makes you lose track of time.

test.question: Identify the type of conjunction in: '‡§§‡•Ä ‡§π‡•Å‡§∂‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡§Ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§Æ‡•á‡§π‡§®‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§ ‡§®‡§æ‡§π‡•Ä.' (She is clever but does not work hard.)
test.explanation: '‡§™‡§∞‡§Ç‡§§‡•Å' means 'but/however' ‚Äî it shows a contrast between two ideas (she is clever, BUT does not work hard). This is a ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§®‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§ï (adversative) conjunction ‚Äî one that shows opposition or contrast between the two parts of the sentence. Other adversative conjunctions: ‡§™‡§£, ‡§§‡§∞‡•Ä, ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞.

test.question: What is the Marathi word for 'library'?
test.explanation: '‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç‡§•‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ø' (granthaalaya) or '‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ø' (vaachanaalaya) means library. ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç‡§• = important book, ‡§Ü‡§≤‡§Ø = place/house ‚Üí house of books. '‡§∂‡§æ‡§≥‡§æ' = school, '‡§∞‡•Å‡§ó‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ø' = hospital (‡§∞‡•Å‡§ó‡•ç‡§£ = patient), '‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ø' = college (‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ = great, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ø = school).

test.question: Fill in the blank with the correct conjunction type: '‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ ‡§ö‡§π‡§æ ‡§π‡§µ‡§æ ___ ‡§ï‡•â‡§´‡•Ä?' (Do you want tea ___ coffee?)
test.explanation: '‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç‡§µ‡§æ' (or) is the ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§ï (alternative) conjunction ‚Äî used when offering a choice between two options. '‡§ö‡§π‡§æ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ï‡•â‡§´‡•Ä?' means 'tea or coffee?' ‚Äî the person can choose one. '‡§Ü‡§£‡§ø' would mean you want BOTH, which is a different situation.

test.question: The conjunction '‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§£‡•Ç‡§®' (mhanun) is which type?
test.explanation: '‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§£‡•Ç‡§®' means 'therefore' or 'so' ‚Äî it shows a cause-and-effect or reason-result relationship. For example: '‡§™‡§æ‡§ä‡§∏ ‡§™‡§°‡§≤‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§£‡•Ç‡§® ‡§∂‡§æ‡§≥‡§æ ‡§¨‡§Ç‡§¶ ‡§ù‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä' (It rained, therefore school was closed). This is a ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§ï (causal) conjunction. Other causal conjunctions: ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ (because), ‡§∏‡§¨‡§¨ (therefore).

test.question: Which of these conjunctions is ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§ï (additive)?
test.explanation: '‡§§‡§∏‡•á‡§ö' means 'as well as' or 'also' ‚Äî it ADDS information, making it a ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§ï (additive) conjunction. '‡§§‡•ã ‡§ö‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ó‡§≤‡§æ ‡§ñ‡•á‡§≥‡§æ‡§°‡•Ç ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á, ‡§§‡§∏‡•á‡§ö ‡§§‡•ã ‡§è‡§ï ‡§ö‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ó‡§≤‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á' ‚Äî He is a good player, and also a good friend. Other additive conjunctions: ‡§Ü‡§£‡§ø, ‡§µ, ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø.

test.question: What is the story saying when the parents initially worried but then supported the child's reading habit?

options.A: Parents should never allow children to read at night
options.B: Books are a waste of time
options.C: Deep reading habits, though seemingly obsessive, lead to positive intellectual and personal growth

test.explanation: The parents' journey from worry to support mirrors a real parental experience. Initially any 'obsession' looks unhealthy. But as they observe their child growing intellectually, developing curiosity, expanding vocabulary and knowledge, they realize that '‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§ö‡•á ‡§µ‡•á‡§°' (passion for reading) is one of the best habits a child can develop.

test.question: Identify the conjunction and its type: '‡§§‡•ã ‡§ò‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§Ü‡§≤‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§ï ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ó‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡•Ä.'
test.explanation: '‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£' means 'because' ‚Äî it is a ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§ï (causal) conjunction that shows the REASON for the action. '‡§§‡•ã ‡§ò‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§Ü‡§≤‡§æ' (He came home) is the result; '‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§ï ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ó‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡•Ä' (because he was hungry) is the reason. '‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£' connects cause and effect.

test.question: Why are conjunctions called '‡§â‡§≠‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•Ä' (ubhaya + anvayi)?

options.A: Because they are used on both sides of a sentence AND they never change form
options.B: Because '‡§â‡§≠‡§Ø' means both/two and '‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•Ä' means connecting ‚Äî they connect both parts
options.C: Because they are used twice in every sentence
options.D: Because they come at the end of every sentence

test.explanation: '‡§â‡§≠‡§Ø' means 'both' or 'two' and '‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•Ä' means 'connecting/joining.' So ‡§â‡§≠‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•Ä = 'connecting both sides.' Conjunctions join two words, two phrases, or two sentences ‚Äî connecting BOTH sides together. The name perfectly describes what conjunctions do.

test.question: The full Marathi term for the grammar type that includes ‡§Ü‡§£‡§ø, ‡§™‡§£, ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç‡§µ‡§æ, ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ is:
test.explanation: ‡§â‡§≠‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•á = Conjunctions (words that join two parts). ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§£ ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•á = Adverbs (describe verbs). ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•á = Postpositions (come after nouns). ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•á = Interjections (expressions of emotion like '‡§Ö‡§∞‡•á!', '‡§µ‡§æ!', '‡§Ö‡§∞‡•á‡§∞‡•á!'). All four end in '‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•á' because they are all indeclinable words.

keyConcepts: Benefits of reading: vocabulary, empathy, knowledge, concentration
Maharashtra's literary tradition ‚Äî Akhil Bharatiya Marathi Sahitya Sammelan
commonMisconceptions: Students often confuse ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§ï conjunctions ‚Äî '‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£' (because) introduces the REASON while '‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§£‡•Ç‡§®' (therefore) introduces the RESULT. Both show cause-effect but from different directions.
Some students think '‡§µ' (and) is not a valid conjunction ‚Äî it is a formal alternative to '‡§Ü‡§£‡§ø' and is correct in written Marathi.
'‡§§‡§∞‡•Ä' (still/yet/even then) is sometimes missed as a conjunction ‚Äî it is a ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§®‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§ï used to show unexpected continuation despite a previous statement.
